{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3608066,"name":"FredK","username":"FredK","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T13:55:53.011Z","cooked":"

We have an old Rio that may have had a short due to metal shavings and we want to test it. Is there a way to test all the pins (including signal) with a voltmeter. We’re pretty new to this.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-04-30T13:55:53.011Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":84.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500941,"topic_slug":"testing-rio-electronics","display_username":"FredK","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/testing-rio-electronics/500941/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3608070,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T14:03:50.352Z","cooked":"

Well, if you think you’ve got a power shorted to ground, then multimeter between the power and ground.

I’d start by disassembling it a cleaning it thoroughly, then firing it up.

What makes you think you have a short?

Basically an urban legend. Rumors that something went wrong with the Rio but no details. It hasn’t been used in a year but never really tested.

If you have no details on what the problem is, it might also be a corrupted firmware issue. I’d still take some time to clean it before attempting anything, just in case it really has a short somewhere.

The Driver Station can report if there is a short on a given part of the Roborio,

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

FRC Driver Station Powered by NI LabVIEW

This article describes the use and features of the FRC ® Driver Station Powered by NI LabVIEW. For information on installing the Driver Station software see this document. Starting the FRC Driver S...

If it turns out to be damaged, you can visit the NI Support page to get an engineer to walk you through some diagnostics, if it’s in bad shape, NI may send you an RMA and replace it.

https://forums.ni.com/t5/Support/ct-p/Support

Echoing @Tom_Line - the majority of Rio issues I’ve ever encountered were solved by opening it up and cleaning it out with a soft bristle brush and vacuum. Rio2 seem much more susceptible to debris causing shorts than the Rio1.
